commentBody: Anything with a kitten on it and I send them money.

There is so much distrust of charitable organizations and family foundations because of revelations about exorbitant salaries, perks, and misuse of funds. Our President of course is a perfect exemplar of this. I also remember the revelations about United Way and Red Cross in particular. I remember being compelled to donate a portion of my low salary to UnitedWay, and I deeply resented it. 
These are some of the reasons so many people prefer to donate via crowd funding to help individuals with specific needs like medical bills.

I have been a longtime donor to St. Jude’s Hospital. I always wondered why they spent so much money constantly sending fancy solicitations to me every month. I feel some of that money can be saved by sending mailings to get new donors, not someone whom they can depend on.

And then over Thanksgiving my daughter revealed to me that the St. Jude’s CEO makes $6.7 million dollars! Why? There is no doubt in my mind that there are many talented and hard working men and women who would do the job for even less than $1 million yearly plus expenses. The millions in savings can go to help even more children and their families.

Yes, CEOs need to be thoughtful, have a vision of the future, good at making sound decisions and eliciting support. But there are lots of people on our society who could be successful CEOs. Being a CEO does not require a talent as rare as that of an athletic star such as Michael Jordon in basketball or Tom Brady in football. It is so harmful to our society that many have come to believe that it does.', 'createDate': '1575567049', 'updateDate': '1575676339', 'approveDate': '1575567056', 'recommendations': 6, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103987983, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'LT', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103991071', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
I have been able to give some of my charity dollars to a different intermediary than an organization.  A minister friend mentioned one day a nurse whose feet were suffering because could not afford the work shoes she needed.  I gave my friend the money for those shoes and she passed it on.  Since then I've been able to "adopt" two families whose stories were told to me, one by a nun and the other by a volunteer doctor at a Native American clinic.  

I am able to send the minister and the families money each month.  It's not a great amount but I know it means more to them.  Sometimes I learn how the donation was spent (e.g. taking a grandmother Christmas shopping).   

I've known each of my sources (minister, nun and doctor) and the work they're doing well and for a long time.  I do contribute to some charitable organizations, but I know that 100% of these special dollars is reaching their targets and probably meeting needs that no formal organization would.

I no longer give to non-profits or "charities" except for token donations like $1 in the Salvation Army bucket. Instead I donate my time, or help fund a project that someone I know is doing. That way I know EXACTLY how my donation is being used.

I used to work at a non-profit substance abuse treatment agency. They had a welfare to work program in which they trained people on welfare to be substance abuse counselors for their programs. The house of cards fell down when employees blew the whistle on the fact they would then fire the new hires to hire more people from the welfare to work program. There is no way to know for sure how your money is being used.

commentBody:
I admit, I find it very hard to donate to organizations where senior executives are making millions in compensation.

For example United Way's CEO makes over $1 million per year.  The CEO of Save the Children makes almost $500k. The CEO of Feeding America makes $800k.

I don't begrudge these executives their compensation, and I am sure many of them are worth it in the total amount of donations they bring into their organizations.  But do they really need my $250?

commentBody:
RE: Know What Your Dollar Buys...

No mention that one million dollars is good for an ambassadorship?

I'm sad to see this piece here in the NYTimes. While being more impactful about development work and certainly caring about what impact your $$ make, it is also important to evaluate organisations that ORGs such as GiveWell recommend on the basis of what GiveWell knows about these organisations. One of the most recommended evidence-based organisations Evidence Action, for example, is grossly guilty of hogwash -read http://bit.ly/2qkhMFo

I wish this article had explored a little deeper on the difference between Give Clean Water and Evidence Action.  I have a very strong hunch that the comparison is not apples to apples, and that one of the charities is not actually 100 times as efficient as the other.  

What, exactly, does it mean to supply a person with a year of potable water?  There is a big difference between purifying water that is already readily available at a site, and bringing water to the site (well, pipeline, or truck) in addition to treating it.  Trying to read between the lines on their websites, that seems to explain much of the difference in their apparent efficiency.

[{'commentID': 103972741, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103972741, 'userID': 74292043, 'userDisplayName': 'mb', 'userLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Davy_G I have the same strong hunch.  

Give Clean Water gives each family a water filter and trains them to use it and maintain it.  Evidence Action installs a chlorine dispenser at a local water source and keeps it filled.  

I can see that the count of "people provided with clean water for a year" per dollar spent would be quite different -- but I don't see that the cheaper alternative is provably better for all circumstances, which is the claim.', 'createDate': '1575496709', 'updateDate': '1575677001', 'approveDate': '1575496710', 'recommendations': 12, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103971343, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Davy_G', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103972741', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
GiveWell is not well respected in the social sector as it has tended to favor friends of the founders and adhere a set of ideological principles that do not appear hold up in practice - i.e. there is an over-reliance on data without understanding the larger picture, context, or systems. They have also been resistant to feedback.

ImpactMatters on the other hand has a much better reputation even though it is a younger organization. It recognizes the complexities of the problems and the range of interventions needed. It also evaluates organizations as to whether they are learning organizations - and they too have been transparent about what they have learned.

I used to work for NGOs.  I am always wary of the “administration costs” metric.  A low one may mask the fact that the charity exploits its employees — low pay, no health care or other benefits, pay-per-piece or treating them as contractors, etc.  
Charity should begin there.
Anyone and everyone who decides to take $1+ out of their earnings and donate it to whatever they want should feel good about that decision.

commentBody:
Prioritizing more effective organizations is important.  Should we give to established ones, or small ones with promise?  

Perhaps before we ask that, we should ask how much?  According to the IRS, in 2010, people at the lowest income level gave the highest as a percentage of their income- about 10%.  The percentage drops to 2.3% or so as you climb the income ladder.  

What can this look like?    If you make $200K/yr , an annual charitable budget would be $20K to match that of the lowest income bracket in the US.  For some context, our public school PTA in the SF Bay Area tries to raise about $400 per student per year, about $160K total for 400 students.  Depending on how you got your house (inheritance, stock options, etc.) $200k can be a decent living.  One can imagine not very many families could take care of this PTA ask, if giving at a rate comparable to what lowest income donors give.

My point is, moderately upper middle class to upper class people can give a lot more.

Wow very interesting. Certainly need to somehow get people more aware of the groups out there doing investigations into effectiveness of donations. Charitable giving is about $427 billion in the US. That's pretty impressive. I also wonder how a generous government assistance program might focus less on selling weapons and advancing likeminded politics than on targeted, effective aid for the most vulnerable of the world's citizens.

The example about helping the blind is a tough one.  Giving to the organization that performs sight-giving surgery is obviously critically important, but does that mean one should not donate to the less efficient guide dog program?  After all, people will still be blind, and they will still need guide dogs.

Poor people, both here and around the world, spend most of their time dealing with the impact of poverty rather than earning money to claw their way out of the dilemma. When you don't have money to pay for anything extra, every setback is a crisis and it consumes great amounts of time resolve what otherwise would be simple problems.

Government programs here accentuate this problem by adding more time consuming tasks, like going from office to office for benefits and the constant need to prove that the person is eligible for the benefits they seek. The system is perverse. It perpetuates poverty conditions. So, too, does the criminal justice system when it comes down hard on people for minor violations.

As for the issue of overhead, it can be both a good measure and a false one. There is a charity in the DC area known as World Central Kitchens founded by a well known chef to feed people after disasters, such as hurricanes. If a good portion of the food is donated, this charity should spend close to 100% of its donations on overhead because of the expense of moving people into disaster zones, putting them up in tents and preparing hundreds of thousands of meals. It is the service that counts.

Longer term, the root causes of poverty and inadequate health care need to be addressed.

Knowing what your charitable dollars buy is very important. But simpleminded comparisons based on number of people helped per dollar rule out some extremely worthwhile causes. Naturally it costs more to train a specially-bred dog for two years to give a blind or disabled person their independence back, than for a basic surgery to remove cataracts or trachoma (done by volunteer surgeons) in Africa. It doesn't mean that the $42,000 is "wasted." Better to look at % of dollars spent on programs and beneficiaries versus "administrative" costs, which Charity Navigator and others already do.
